These videos have to be among the most ineffectual ways you could possibly teach someone. Information is thrown at you in blocks of non-sequiturs and equations.   No context or reasoning is given for the conclusions shown, you’re just expected to accept the shiny equations on the screen one after the other, and a good number of things here are stated in such a odd, simplified way that it borders on complete misinformation.   I understood everything stated here, but that’s because I’ve been through university physics and I winced multiple times throughout this video as things are explained in such a cavalier way.   Crash Course should stick to talking about the Napoleonic Wars or something because they clearly don’t have the skills to talk meaningfully about subjects such as this.

6:32 I think this is the opposite. The mark Xs indicate the magnetic field goes from the front to the back of the screen. If you move the loop like this, the total magnetic flow penetrating the area of the loop decreases. So you can guess the current will flow to create the magnetic field to oppose this decrease of magnetic flux. In this case, the current should go in the opposite direction as shown in the video.  Please correct if I’m wrong.

I'm a little confused with one thing; in the magnetic flux equation, she says that cos theta is one if the angle between the magnetic field a line are perpendicular. But if the line is perpendicular, wouldn't the angle be 90 degrees by definition? That would make cosine theta zero and ruin the equation. I think I'm missing something, but I don't know what.
More in put more in put

You're right. She didnt explain that part very well. She meant to say that if the angle between the magnetic field  and the line perpendicular to the FACE of the loop is zero i.e the two vectors are parallel (which gives cos 0 = 1), that would mean that the angle between the magnetic field and the loop itself would be perpendicular.

At 6:33 isn't the current direction in the wire the opposite of what it should be? Downward Flux is decreasing, so induction wants to increase downward flux which means current should be moving clockwise

All a bunch of math! But do people realize what is physically happening? That the moving magnetic field only catalyzes a copper atom to become a battery, by forcing an abnormal gyroscopic procession of its electron, and this abnormal procession is what causes free electrons in the wire to be pushed down the wire.

All a bunch of math! But do people realize what is physically happening? That the moving magnetic field only catalyzes a copper atom to become a battery, by forcing an abnormal gyroscopic procession of its electron, and this abnormal procession is what causes free electrons in the wire to be pushed down the wire.

This is not a lecture (i..e. Not a purposeful attempt to a) convey knowledge previously proven via consistent outcomes in real life/everyday applications, AND b) explain said information via the utilisation of several practical descriptive examples of and/or several practical physical applications of the information covered by that lecture). Instead, this young lady, who seems to be quite knowledgeable regarding the topic of this presentation, is simply reciting information. Although I am familiar with the topic of EM Induction, usw, usf... I found this presentation to be uninteresting and reminiscent of a lecture on speed-reading. Sadly, these issues are not uncommon in the field of online „education”. Thank you for allowing me to share these opinions and perspective on your channel. May you live in peace. Salome.

That’s actually not true. You can think of it as the voltage across a battery but not just as voltage because you can’t calculate the voltage when the electric field is “loopy”. They’re similar but not the same. Emf is the line integral around a closed loop but voltage difference would be zero around a closed loop because it’s path independent.
@jadeg1154  The potential is just the gradient of the E-field. Therefore if the curl of the E-field is non-zero, a closed line integral would therefore generally also be non-zero.
Maybe that will be helpful if you want to grasp the idea, what essentially they are not the same, and it is good to know that when you are deep into studying -let alone before sitting for the exam!

Pedro Galeano I’m aware they’re not the same, but for basic understanding it’s a great starting point if you don’t have the overall idea - I just found it simpler to understand it this way before going into technical differences!

Thought the same thing at first. She said 'perpendicular to the loop' which made me think 90, but that's not the  angle in the Faraday's Law. Theta is between the original magnetic field and the loop's AREA VECTOR, where the area vector is, itself, perpendicular to the loop's plane.  "Weird flux, but ok."

the area vector is perpendicular to the surface of the area, the area vector is shown as 'A'  with an arrow on top ofc  And if the Magnetic field is perpendicular to the surface of the area as well then the angle between A(Area) and B(Magnetic Field) is 0 ( cos0=1 )  Magnetic flux is the dot product of B and A :)
teokk1 angle betweeen magnetic field vector and the vector normal to the surface.

She said theta is the angle between the magnetic field and a line perpendicular to the face of the loop So when it's a magnetic field (horizontal in this video) which is perpendicular to the loop.....Then theta would be zero Hence cos(0) is 1

The equation for emf was negative magnetic flux over change in time; however, in the later equation, the equation for emf equals magnetic field times the length times velocity. There was no negative sign. I need an explanation for this.

@DM-ce6su  No, it is correct. I know that the magnetic field generated by the current is in the same direction as the magnetic field of the magnet (over the north pole). But the magnet is moving down, so the change in the magnetic field is in the opposite direction. And so you have used the Lenz law in the correct way. However, if I haven't made any mistankes, then I think the example of the loop moving out of the magnetic field is wrong. The change in the magnetic field (flux) is pointing up, just as the magnetic field generated by the current. And that is violating Lenz law.

sfruizmiranda, I did little study and I figured that the equation is right. The angle mentioned is wrong. Look at the following table. Consider equation BA*cos(angle)  Angle         induced e.m.f    0                  max positive   90                 min means zero 180                 max negative 270                 min means zero   0                    max positive  Sorry about confusing you before.
its ok @Govind Lohiya. Thank you!

For those confused or mislead by these comments:  the cos(theta) is the cos of the angle between the magnetic field and "normal to the plane of the loop".  Perpendicular, as in the example from the video, means that angle would be zero.  Cos(0) = 1 and will provide the Magnetic Flux maximum.  The angle is zero in this example.
The terminology to use here is " parallel to plane ", not perpendicular.

THETA = angle between magnetic field & a line perpendicular to the face of loop.  When magnetic field itself is perpendicular to the face of loop, the THETA becomes 0.  Hence cos ( THETA ) = cos ( 0 ) = 1 Hope this clears the confusion...
Govind Lohiya EY...u should know it is scalar product flux=B•∆S=B∆S cos(@)

It's false. She said the generated magnetic field points upward so the current flows clockwise, but what she should have said was that the change in magnetic flux is pointing up, which means the generated magnetic field is pointing down, thus a clockwise current rotation.

This makes a lot more sense if you describe Faraday's Law as e-induced is dø/dt. For a magnetic field (that doesn't change as a function of space) Ø=B•A, as you said. So Emf=dø/dt=B(dA/dt)+A(dB/dt) by the product rule. So a change in magnetic field with respect to time or a change in area with respect to time induces an Emf! This is an easier way to see what's going on for that type of B-field.
